ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
cybersecrity,
sensitive information,
social networks and privacy
I learned about private data through the economic, legal, social, and technical lenses.
This course taught me a lot about the role sensitive information plays in society today, and especially how it relates to cyber security
I learned a ton about cybersecurity, privacy, and how these issues impact our daily lives. I also realized how important it is to consider cybersecurity as a computer scientist.

Insights - I learned a lot about privacy (or more accurately, the lack thereof) with a lot of the technology in our lives. It was definitely eye-opening to see the huge extent to which our sensitive information was being handed to third-parties and sold and passed around

Knowledge - I learned about the economic, political, and social factors that contributed to privacy concerns. 

Skills - Presentation and essay writing, though because it is a CS class, I felt like the level of expectation of writing was lower than the average Yale course and didn't really learn much from it.
Knowledge about how our data online can easily be misused.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel like this class would have been better as a seminar with more class discussions.
This course felt largely taught by the students through their presentations and leading class discussions; depending on who you ask, that can be a strength or a weakness

I think Prof. Fischer can sometimes speak really slowly which makes it hard to follow sometimes because I would get distracted. I also loved hearing from the guest speakers and wish we had a few more.

Strengths - low workload, interesting and important subject matter

Weaknesses - Professor Fischer isn't the most exciting of lecturers. Although I thought he was very nice and sweet, his lecturers definitely could be kind of dry and boring. Also most people were taking this for a gut cs class so a lot of the class wasn't engaged, which was a shame since it was a discussion seminar. 

How it could be improved - bring in more guest speakers, more engagement from the class.
For the strengths, the class was very interactive .

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, more discussion and brainstorm, intersting
I would for a low workload cs elective.
I would definitely take this course as a CS major looking for an elective. Its a pretty chill class and you get exposed to a lot of topics relating to sensitive data and cyber security

yes, if youre able to independently engage with the material which is really interesting. Class itself could sometimes be slow. Also a good CS elective to take to balance out a programming intensive class like 323.

I would not recommend this course to another student. I would recommend CS majors to resist the temptation of an easy gut and instead take something more substantive and interesting. Although the course matter is very important, I do not think the class was well taught or organized enough to be taken.
I would in the sense that it is very informative.
